bestBHT.bht: The acceptable year of the Lord alludes to the jubilee year, a time when liberty and release were proclaimed to all. It does not imply that Jesus' ministry lasted only a year, as some Church Fathers suggested. Instead, it showcases Christ as the glorious healer who addresses the various afflictions of humanity. By proclaiming the acceptable year, Jesus declares the arrival of the Messianic age, where the blessings of the jubilee year extend to all. This highlights the divine mission and message of Christ, bringing forth God's grace and the fulfillment of His purpose.

Henry Alford: the acceptable year of the Lord... liberty was proclaimed to all in the land in the year of jubilee."

No countenance is given by this expression to the extraordinary inference from it of some of the Fathers (Clement of Alexandria, Origen), that the Lord’s public ministry lasted only a year, and something over.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: allusion to the jubilee year, a year of universal release for person and property.

The first words, 'THE SPIRIT of the LORD is upon ME,' have been noted since the days of the Church Fathers, as an illustrious example of Father, Son, and Holy Ghost being exhibited as in distinct yet harmonious action in the scheme of salvation.

As the maladies under which humanity groans are here set forth under the names of poverty, broken-heartedness, bondage, blindness, bruisedness (or crushedness), so, as the glorious HEALER of all these maladies, Christ announces Himself in the act of reading it.
Albert Barnes: The gospel assures us that the guilty 'may' return, and that God will graciously receive them.

There is, perhaps, here, an allusion to the year of jubilee - the fiftieth year, when the trumpet was blown, and through the whole land proclamation was made of the liberty of Hebrew slaves, of the remission of debts, and of the restoration of possessions to their original families.
The phrase 'the acceptable year' means the time when it would be acceptable to God to proclaim such a message, or agreeable to him - to wit, under the gospel.
Marvin Vincent: To preach (Rev., proclaim) the acceptable year of the Lord.
Liberty is to be proclaimed to all in that year.
A literal interpretation of the word year gave rise among some of the Christian fathers to the theory that our Lord's ministry lasted but a single year.
John Calvin: He therefore makes the time of redemption to depend on the purpose, or good pleasure, of God.
Paul calls it the fullness of the time, that believers may learn not to indulge in excessive curiosity, but to acquiesce in the will of God.
Salvation was manifested in Christ, at the time which seemed good in the sight of God.
Philip Schaff: The acceptable year of the Lord. The year, or definite appointed period, when the Lord is gracious.
Not without a reference to the year of jubilee, which also pointed to the Messiah’s coming and kingdom.
It proves nothing as to the length of our Lord’s ministry.
Archibald T. Robertson: The Messianic age has come, Jesus means to say.
On the first day of the year of Jubilee the priests with sound of trumpet proclaimed the blessings of that year.
This great passage justly pictures Christ's conception of his mission and message.
John Gill: The time which he willed and fixed for the redemption of his people, and in which he showed his goodwill and pleasure unto sinful men.
The sufferings of Christ were according to his will; his sacrifice was of a sweet smelling savour to him; his righteousness he was well pleased with.
All Christ did, and suffered, were grateful to God, because hereby his perfections were glorified, his purposes, counsel, and covenant were accomplished, and his people saved.
John Wesley: The acceptable year — Plainly alluding to the year of jubilee, when all, both debtors and servants, were set free.

bhtAttempts.bht: The acceptable year of the Lord refers to the year of jubilee, symbolizing the time when liberty and release were proclaimed to all in the land. This phrase does not imply that Jesus' ministry only lasted a year. Instead, it highlights the holistic healing that Christ offers, addressing poverty, broken-heartedness, bondage, blindness, and bruisedness. The proclamation of the acceptable year signifies the arrival of the Messianic age, where the blessings and freedom of the jubilee year are extended to all. This passage provides a powerful insight into Christ's mission and message, emphasizing God's saving grace and the fulfillment of His divine purpose.

The acceptable year of the Lord alludes to the jubilee year, a time when liberty and release were proclaimed to all. It does not imply that Jesus' ministry lasted only a year, as some Church Fathers suggested. Instead, it showcases Christ as the glorious healer who addresses the various afflictions of humanity. By proclaiming the acceptable year, Jesus declares the arrival of the Messianic age, where the blessings of the jubilee year extend to all. This highlights the divine mission and message of Christ, bringing forth God's grace and the fulfillment of His purpose.

The acceptable year of the Lord in Luke 4:19 is a reference to the jubilee year, when liberty was proclaimed to all. Contrary to the idea that Jesus' ministry lasted only a single year, this phrase signifies the arrival of the Messianic age and the holistic healing that Christ offers. By addressing poverty, broken-heartedness, bondage, blindness, and bruisedness, Jesus's mission as the great healer is proclaimed. This passage beautifully portrays the divine conception of Christ's purpose and message.

The acceptable year of the Lord is a direct allusion to the jubilee year, when liberty and release were proclaimed to all. This phrase carries no implications about the duration of Jesus' ministry. Instead, it emphasizes Christ as the glorious healer, addressing poverty, broken-heartedness, bondage, blindness, and bruisedness. By proclaiming the acceptable year, Jesus declares the arrival of the Messianic age, extending the blessings of the jubilee year to all. This profound expression highlights Christ's divine mission and message, revealing God's saving grace and the fulfillment of His purpose.

The acceptable year of the Lord in Luke 4:19 refers to the year of jubilee, when liberty was proclaimed to all. It does not support the idea of Jesus' ministry lasting only a year. Instead, it showcases Christ as the glorious healer who addresses poverty, broken-heartedness, bondage, blindness, and bruisedness. The proclamation of the acceptable year signifies the arrival of the Messianic age, where the blessings and freedom of the jubilee year are extended to all. This passage beautifully captures Christ's mission and message, emphasizing God's saving grace and the fulfillment of His purpose.
